Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second examines "displacement." Casey argues that modern culture prioritizes time as the organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time" or "saving time." He suggests centering culture around place instead, fostering a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book is the first to truly captivate me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the thirteenth time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I am math-phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and answered the door. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced, the doorbell rang again. Bam—my breakthrough vanished. I checked once more, but no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

GOP Faces Criticism Over Recruitment  
Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are being relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy  

The Jacksonville citizenship ceremony appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before leaving the June 29 event, an immigration official encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common practice. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members.  

Linda Cross, there to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation suspicious.

Urllink welcomes the newest Atom/RSS/RDF reader on the scene: PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software. Packed with native app features, it’s worth noting this isn’t a free offering—a recurring debate online. You can test it for 15 days before deciding to switch back or purchase it for $25. The aiming reticle is too small, and the zoom feels underpowered. Despite these flaws, it’s been a blast. I’m not usually a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and FPS/beat-em-up gameplay is fantastic. I play as often as possible—just one more mission, one more supply run, or fleeing to safety before quitting.

An absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I can confidently say this one stands out. The unit variety is impressive—while I don’t know the exact count, there’s a massive selection! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the gameplay is truly epic. The in-game chat box on the main menu is surprisingly entertaining—no joke. However, if you think this game is "easy" or are new to strategy games, expect a steep learning curve. Don’t get discouraged; you’ll lose plenty of units. Just plan carefully, prioritize anti-air and anti-tank units, and adapt.

I was initially skeptical about this game and hesitant to buy it. The portal gun mechanic seemed odd to me, despite my love for science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting are phenomenal—genuinely impressive. While occasionally cheesy, the jokes land well, and each character has a distinct sense of humor. Their personalities shine through brilliantly. The level design is outstanding, too. For context, I haven’t played the first Portal game, but I plan to when I have time. I wouldn’t have tried this sequel otherwise.

It’s one of the best multiplayer games out there, perfect when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and absolutely loving this game—it's hilarious! The gameplay is solid, the art design stunning, and the music surprisingly high-quality and fitting. The story and world are engaging, and the puzzles are enjoyable. But the standout feature is the comedy. Whether you're an RPG veteran or new to the genre, the humor shines through with clever jokes, parodies, and references. *Final Fantasy VII* or *X* fans, in particular, shouldn't miss this. I had to pause after two hours just to rest my cheeks from laughing so much. What a delightful experience so far!

I’m genuinely sorry, as I try to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn’t enjoy this one. The premise seemed perfect for me, but the execution fell flat. While I love puzzle and exploration games, I found this one unintuitive—even after consulting guides, the gameplay just wasn’t fun. It also lacks a pause button (or if it exists, I couldn’t find it), which feels like a major oversight given the timed sequences. Additionally, the game feels more like a series of cutscenes than actual gameplay, leaving me impatient and disengaged.

This game... where do I even begin? It was absolutely stunning, from the story to the graphics—I was completely hooked. The narrative wasn’t just a tale; it felt like I *was* the protagonist, unraveling each twist alongside them. The gameplay was fantastic, and I even discovered something about myself (mainly my fear of heights, which only surfaced in the ice caverns). My stomach churned the entire time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you ever release a DLC or sequel, I’d be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thank you to everyone involved—you’ve created a masterpiece.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory.' Unlike previous titles set along Earth's historical timeline—spanning the Stone Age, Medieval era, and Modern Age—this installment takes place in the future as you colonize a new planet. What I appreciate most is 2K's fresh approach, introducing mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions can occasionally feel overwhelming. One area for improvement could be incorporating new artwork, particularly in environments seen during leader interactions, to enhance immersion.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience—definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever. Edit: After 60+ hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. Designed like a survival horror, you must conserve ammo, treat wounds, and manage infections. The zombies feel natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play title. P.S.: I’d recommend playing with 1–2 friends, but the community is super friendly, so you can easily team up or chat via text/voice.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn’t particularly deep or compelling, but the storytelling elevates it. The atmosphere is immersive, and the collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing out the world. I learned a lot about Batman’s universe, though the lack of bosses was disappointing. Still, future games can address that. Combat strikes a good balance, leaning slightly toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman felt underwhelming, but upgrading and acquiring gadgets introduced engaging new mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas created a satisfying sense of progression.

To the Moon" is no mere game—it’s a profound experience, and one of the finest I’ve ever had. Think *The Walking Dead* by Telltale is sad? Well, it pales in comparison to this. Never before has fiction left me so heartbroken yet fulfilled. This masterpiece epitomizes storytelling at its peak, with a soundtrack that’s both charming and flawless. While the controls can be finicky and gameplay isn’t its forte, the narrative is so captivating that it hardly matters. The humor is delightful, never undermining the story’s depth. And the *Doctor Who* references? Endless.

Bastion is an outstanding game with a compelling storyline. Set after a catastrophic event, you begin rebuilding the world from the bastion. The game offers abundant choices, from constructing upgrades to selecting weapons, power-ups, and bonus-enhancing drinks. Its art style and music are exceptional, proving that post-apocalyptic settings need not be dreary. The vibrant visuals add depth to the experience. Most impressively, the game features dynamic narration that reacts to your actions. For instance, if you swap weapons in the armory, the narrator comments on your choice, making the gameplay feel uniquely personal. Every decision you make shapes both the world and the story.

I originally purchased this game during its early development, when spacebux was the sole currency and there was no "tech tree." Back then, the game was truly enjoyable. Every gun was equally overpowered, eliminating any balance issues—anyone could defeat anyone at any moment. Additionally, players had unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. For a game boasting "bajillions of guns," you'd expect more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for extras. At one point, I owned roughly three pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more—that’s where I found the fun.

This game was a delightful surprise. While rave reviews can often be misleading, here they perfectly capture the fun of this charming little title. It blends a classic 2D platformer with MOBA elements seamlessly and stylishly. I unexpectedly enjoyed characters I'd typically avoid in other MOBAs. Though skeptical, I tried a melee tank and was pleasantly surprised—leading me to experiment with more as they unlocked. The art style and interface have a quirky appeal. I now use one character as my avatar and even a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours. It's been a while since a game captivated me like this. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. Every combat encounter excites me, and the system is brilliantly optimized. I had doubts about the naval combat, but destroying multiple fleets is incredibly fun! The only way to lose is failing to retreat. If combat seems overwhelming, just retreat, regroup, and strike back. Thanks, devs, for an amazing experience!

The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may initially resist these alterations, the new direction ultimately benefits the character—a fact *Ninja Theory*’s latest installment convincingly demonstrates. *DmC* serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers, tracing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and charting his transformation into selflessness. The game crafts a clear, engaging narrative arc for this reimagined hero, making his journey compelling to witness. The story follows Dante as he confronts the corrupt world he once willfully ignored.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with detail, and brimming with happiness—bad puns, mischievous dogs, and hidden secrets included. It balances seriousness with humor effortlessly. The character design shines, featuring diverse personalities and intriguing backstories. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the option to complete it without killing anyone—a rare and refreshing concept. Drawing inspiration from *EarthBound*, one of the finest RPGs, it’s clear this game is something special. Plus, its soundtrack is the best I’ve heard in years.

I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor emotionally moved. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction. The other half attempts to depict mental decline through themes of obsession, hallucination, and depression. While the concept is intriguing in theory, the execution fell short. The entire 'game' took me just 10 minutes to complete, even while carefully reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why *Portal* is amazing? It's a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps back, offering a brilliant way to challenge your mind while remaining fun. Though not heavily story-driven, it spawned one of the most beloved games of 2011. I still revisit and complete it when bored, marveling at what birthed a legend—and what *is* a legend.  

**Gameplay:** *Portal*'s mechanics are simple to explain. You use portals strategically, alongside buttons that activate puzzle elements. There are two button types: one you press and another requiring a cube.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two—one minor and the other quite annoying—both now resolved, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120) and are seeking a space exploration game, I highly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine: i5 6600k (~€200), Radeon RX 480 (~€200), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70). At ~€650, this rig falls within the mid-range price bracket, though it’s relatively new. I maintain nearly constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. I’m baffled by claims of overkill setups yielding 20 FPS.

Remember *Age of Mythology*? It’s been ages since we’ve seen an RTS of that caliber. *Divinity: Dragon Commander* comes remarkably close to being my personal favorite. Pair that with a grand strategy mode reminiscent of *Risk*, and it truly delivers. I won’t deny my bias—being able to transform into a dragon, supporting troops, attacking, and managing unit production simultaneously is incredible.  

These days, I appreciate complex RTS games like *Civ V*. Yet, many try to cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single overwhelming experience.

Undertale combines its elements to create something extraordinary. The retro-style graphics and soundtrack are strong on their own, but together they craft breathtaking, emotional moments. The writing seamlessly shifts from hilarious to tragic to uplifting—often simultaneously—while cleverly subverting RPG conventions. This doesn’t even cover the world, characters, story, or gameplay, each deserving essays of praise. Instead, I’ll keep it simple: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you love video games, play this game. If you have seven spare hours in your lifetime, play this game.

I’ve only had this game for a few months, yet in that short time, two DLCs have been released alongside patches that transformed an already great game into an exceptional one. The developers are highly engaged with the community, evident in forums and dev diaries. Though the mechanics have a steep learning curve—I’m still mastering them—the depth of strategy offers countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. To me, the game feels nearly infinitely replayable. Every session draws me in, no matter how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the first few hours. After that initial thrill, however, you’ll notice the combat, enemies, and gameplay become repetitive. The standout feature is the developers’ dedication, with semi-frequent updates that introduce sweeping changes, new Warframes, and other tweaks. It’s a solid casual experience, though unlikely to hold your interest beyond a few months unless you love grinding. The best part? It’s free, so it’s worth a try. If you’re after a quick gaming fix, give it a shot.

This game is incredibly dull. I purchased it believing it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a beloved PS2 title. Unfortunately, it falls far short. The gameplay involves absorbing progressively larger objects to grow bigger, but the mechanics are clunky, the levels uninspired, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you questioning existence. Every "living" creature, from pets to humans, makes me wonder if the developers had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was excited when I first heard about this game. I thought, *Wow! A simulator about becoming president—that sounds fun!* Well, it wasn’t. The game forces you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still hopeful, I continued to explore. I’ll give the game credit—the character customization, though limited, is fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you can choose whether to wear your head in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3’s story was superior. Settlements disrupt the narrative, making you resent babysitting them instead of progressing. Some keys are hardcoded and unchangeable. Bugs are rampant—my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to use console commands. Power armor lacks effort; it’s handed to you early, and fusion cores are overly abundant, diminishing its value compared to past games. The story is mediocre, as is most of the game, though it’s more stable than Fallout 3’s frequent crashes. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. New Vegas? No. This title was vastly overhyped for its disappointing quality.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures converge on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will address pressing issues, from China's economic influence to Iraq's post-election future. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the 20+ heads of state attending. Unlike past years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued, with anti-globalization activists canceling a planned weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, Porto Alegre, Brazil, will host the rival World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with Davos' high-profile event.

The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal is approaching, with Fiat and General Motors (GM) having until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. By this deadline, Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as stipulated in their 2000 alliance agreement. GM, struggling with losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to acquire Fiat’s unprofitable unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday amid hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the agreement, claiming it was invalidated when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM’s stake through a capital increase. The original deal emerged from a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticised the Iraq War, stating that billions spent on conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to alleviate poverty. He made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have voiced opposition to the conflict. Speaking on BBC Radio 4’s *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that "billions" were spent on war rather than lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The cardinal urged that 2005 become the year to campaign and "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* missed out on director and screenplay honors, with no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress category to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were overlooked for supporting actor awards. The UK’s Andrea Arnold won the short film prize for her gritty drama *Wasp*. Arnold, a former children’s TV presenter in the 1980s, called the win "totally overwhelming." *Wasp* follows a struggling single mother, triumphing over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for co-writing the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has died in Los Angeles at age 54 after battling cancer. Hill collaborated with director John Carpenter on the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter hunted by a masked killer. The movie grossed over $60 million worldwide—a record for independent cinema at the time. She also partnered with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, Hill started as a production assistant and rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant and second-unit director before her creative partnership with Carpenter. A trailblazer for women in film, she took on roles in the 70s typically dominated by men.

Broadband fuels online expression, as fast web access encourages more people to share their thoughts digitally, research suggests. A quarter of UK broadband users regularly upload content or maintain personal sites, according to a report by think-tank Demos. Fast, always-on connections are transforming internet usage, it notes. Over five million UK households now have broadband, with adoption rapidly increasing. The study examined broadband's impact on online behavior, revealing that more than half of users log on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking at night to browse. Most notably, the report argues broadband is fostering greater online participation.

Yukos is set to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday as it battles for survival. The Russian oil and gas company is being dismantled by authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for U.S. bankruptcy, aiming to leverage international business law to stop the forced sale of its key unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state-owned Rosneft after the auction faced disruptions. Yukos lawyers argue the sale violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its major shareholders have pledged to pursue legal action against any buyer of its assets, using all available means.

Voters are flocking to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, honoring the best web blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site faced such heavy traffic that it temporarily shut down due to overwhelming visitors. Weblogs are competing in 30 categories, ranging from top regional blog to best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a leading US dictionary declaring "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors roughly six million blogs and reports over 12,000 new additions daily. According to Pew Internet and American Life, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, yet fewer than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to state media. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam persists in work on the Xiluodu Dam, reported *Beijing News*. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects suspended due to insufficient environmental reviews. *Beijing News* noted the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop work at two other sites—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandatory environmental assessments have adhered to the shutdown directive.

Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought 2-0 win over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney capitalized on Gary Neville's cross, firing a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne to give United the lead. Seven minutes later, Dunne's misfortune continued as he volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. City squandered their best opportunity when Steve McManaman shot wide from close range in the first half.  

United initially struggled to assert dominance, their play more sluggish than measured, creating only one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar. Despite this, they secured the crucial victory to stay in the title race.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons, who highlights the need to address waiting lists by learning from England's approach. On his first full day in office following Jane Hutt's dismissal, he acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained that the "essentials" were in place. Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, urged policy changes. Ms. Hutt defended her tenure, stating waiting times represented "only 10% of the health agenda." Ms. Hutt's five-and-a-half-year term as Wales' first health minister was notably challenged by lengthy waiting lists.

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' resilient performance in their 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game this season—a fantastic, end-to-end match with excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We displayed tremendous character and determination. I knew we wouldn’t lose.  

"Looking at this fixture, we’ve already won here, while Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit, and Villa might be stronger by then." Ferguson also lauded veterans Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O’Shea. "Roy brought much-needed composure to midfield—a quality no one else possesses.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will screen in the festival's Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film explores Michael's career and personal journey, from his Wham! days to recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into his early years with Wham!, his solo career, legal disputes with Sony Records, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart integrates download sales data, previously limited to a separate chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" ranks second on Billboard's Pop chart and leads its digital chart. The UK singles chart will also incorporate download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These will now be combined with physical singles and airplay data for the updated Hot 100. A second new chart, the Pop 100, merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit the net's self-proclaimed "spam king" hard, forcing him to seek bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the figure behind OptInRealBig.com and countless junk emails, cited lawsuits as the reason for filing Chapter 11. The company faced multiple legal challenges, including a high-profile case from Microsoft demanding millions in damages. OptInRealBig claimed the bankruptcy filing would allow it to address legal issues while continuing operations. Ranked third globally by Spamhaus, the firm was sued in December 2003 for breaching anti-spam laws. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer accused Richter and associates of sending billions of spam messages through 514 hijacked IPs across 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has dismissed claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Reports suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role. "It is absolutely untrue," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "His resignation was solely due to personal reasons. He recently confirmed this to me, stating it was entirely his own matter." Arnesen admitted he couldn't clarify the issues behind Santini's departure after just 13 games. "Jacques never elaborated, but I trust his decision. We must respect it," he added.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put Ireland ahead by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and Ronan O'Gara's third penalty, contributing 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the win. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side now looks forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road. Scotland, struggling to convert pressure into points, will aim for their first Six Nations win under Matt Williams when Italy visits Edinburgh.

Britain's economic future will take center stage in Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. Speaking after the cabinet's final pre-election meeting at No. 10, he stated voters would acknowledge Labour's record of stability and growth while pledging to maintain this progress. Meanwhile, the Conservatives unveiled plans to address antisocial behavior, and the Liberal Democrats expanded on their proposal to abolish council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury urged all three parties to avoid exploiting public fears during the campaign. In an open letter, he cautioned against turning the election into a contest of who could best alarm voters regarding terrorism, immigration, and crime.

Brizzel to compete in AAA's in Sheffield  
Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European Indoor hopefuls racing at this weekend's AAA's Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected for the Europeans who will skip Sheffield. Brizzel aims to defend his 200m title in the British trials.  

In-form James McIlroy looks to secure his spot in the British team for Madrid by claiming the 800m title. McIlroy has excelled on the European circuit recently and ranks among the world's fastest this winter, virtually guaranteeing his place in Madrid.  

Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek he would join Cragg at the European Championships. Carroll currently holds third in the world 3000m rankings, with Cragg leading.

England rugby union captain Jason Robinson is aiming for dual-code success against Australia on Saturday. Robinson, who transitioned from rugby league in 2000, will lead England at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Defeating the Aussies in both matches would be incredible, particularly for league," said Robinson. England, having secured back-to-back autumn wins over Canada and South Africa, seek redemption for June's 51-15 loss to the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could break a 34-year drought against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

"Warning over tsunami aid scam: Internet users are urged to avoid a fraudulent website claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears credible as it mimics an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no ties to the fake site and has reported it to the police. This is just one of many scams exploiting the goodwill sparked by the tsunami tragedy. The link to the fraudulent site is distributed via a circulating spam email with the subject line *"Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal."* The message contains the poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq will invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. Local, Arab, and foreign companies are eligible to bid, according to Iraq's Ministry of Communications. The winning firms will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed-line network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry seeks to raise Iraq's "very low telephone penetration rate from 4.5% today to 25% within 10 years" and develop a "dynamic telecommunications sector." Bidding details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February, with an investor roadshow planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women and older adults are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against cyber threats, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing antivirus, anti-spam, and anti-spyware software rose by 11.2% annually from 2002 to 2004. The study, conducted for cybersecurity firm Preventon, reveals that security awareness is spreading across diverse internet users. Approximately 40% of home cybersecurity software buyers are retirees, with purchases increasing by an average of 13.2% over three years. Notably, retired women (53%) outnumbered retired men in acquiring security software. This research highlights shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, alongside growing recognition of the heightened risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts signify the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or similar digital music player can store up to 10,000 songs—ample space to fill. Increasingly, users are populating that space with audio content from diverse creators. This trend, called "podcasting," is championed by former MTV host Adam Curry. Though named after the iPod, no Apple device is needed to create or enjoy podcasts. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, often produced at home. All that's required is a microphone, a computer, and basic editing software. Creators upload their shows online, allowing free downloads for listeners worldwide.

Andrea Levy, winner of the Orange Prize, has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award for *Small Island*. She now leads as the favorite to secure the overall prize, surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst’s *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean earned the Children’s Fiction Award for *Not the End of the World*, her third win. Category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. Judges Sir Trevor McDonald, Hugh Grant, and Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to select the winner, announced that evening. Bookmaker William Hill rates Levy’s novel the 6/4 favorite.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm that acquired its primary asset. Yukos plans to sue Baikal and others involved in the $20bn sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. Its US legal team will push to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a US court order halting the sale. Baikal's origins and motives remain unclear. Russian media allege Baikal—which purchased Yuganskneftegas for $9.4bn at a state-backed auction—has strong ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, sealing the win with two early goals. Lee Miller struck within the first minute, nodding Jamie McAllister's free-kick over Colin Meldrum from 10 yards. McAllister then doubled the lead, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the far post. Craig Easton pulled one back controversially after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out, allowing McAllister to deliver a pinpoint free-kick that Miller headed over the stranded keeper. Just 10 minutes in, Mikoliunas surged down the right and found McAllister, who powered his header past Meldrum to put the game beyond Livingston.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service enabling customers to rent substantial computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage on Sun-maintained systems. Grid computing, the latest industry buzzword, reflects Sun's belief that computing capacity is as vital as hardware and software. The company compares this shift to the evolution of electricity, suggesting the system may mature similarly to utilities like power and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a dollar an hour?" asked Sun's COO Jonathan Schwartz during a webcast at the company's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigots  

Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted football fans that she aims to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among several measures under consideration in the Scottish Executive’s campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. However, the minister emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a priority.  

Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of Sunday’s Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead. The sectarianism long tied to segments of both clubs' support has become a key focus for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with fan representatives to discuss the matter.

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of *Beyond the Sea* in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, a tribute to 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my homage to a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who performs all 18 songs on the soundtrack as Darin. Bosworth, 21, portrays Darin's wife, real-life actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, accompanied by her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

The Tykes have signed Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen joins from Narbonne. Raphael Ibañez starts at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also named in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell at outside centre.

Home phones face an uncertain future, as the fixed-line telephone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people rely solely on their mobile phones for all calls. The study indicates that over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now use only a mobile. While some retain fixed-line phones due to lower call charges, most respondents agreed that the future is undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored study highlighted distinct usage patterns: home phones were preferred for longer calls, while mobile conversations tended to be shorter and with friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents still used fixed phones primarily because they were cheaper than mobiles.

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber with 70% elected members. MPs and peers have struggled to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can secure support to remove the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government delayed plans to eliminate them, citing opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair insists consensus is necessary for reforms. Suggestions indicate Labour’s manifesto may propose altering at least the Lords' powers.

Disappointed Scott in solid start  
Allan Scott remains confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a strong debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot placed fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was a learning curve, but I’m still aiming for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos won the race, equalling the Spanish record, with Sweden’s Robert Kronberg second and Haiti’s Dudley Dorival third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his final run, clocking 7.64secs in his heat but 0.04secs slower in the final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a set date. The unnamed Georgia plaintiff claims a chip inside the cartridge falsely signals the printer to refill even when unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. purchasers of HP inkjet printers since February 2001. HP, the world's leading printer manufacturer, declined to comment. Their cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt replacements. However, the suit alleges these chips also deactivate cartridges by a predetermined date, regardless of remaining ink.

Virgin Radio is set to become the world's first station to broadcast via 3G mobile networks. Partnering with technology firm Sydus, the station will be available on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from Virgin's website to access the service.  

James Cridland, Virgin Radio's Head of New Media, stated: "This places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will lead the rollout, followed by its digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove.  

Cridland added: "This app will allow anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio with just their phone.

Roxy Music is set to perform at June's Isle of Wight Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, running from 10-12 June. Original members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday night. The band is also working on new material in the studio, their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining later, Roxy Music's first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*. Other hits include *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the Aid Match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid Match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami complete the Northern contingent. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fundraiser at Twickenham. "I'm excited to work with such exceptional players," Woodward remarked. The match offers him a chance to evaluate potential picks before announcing his British and Irish Lions squad for their summer tour of New Zealand. "It promises to be a thrilling spectacle," he added.

The comedy *Sideways* dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, sweeping all six categories for which it was nominated. It claimed Best Film, while Alexander Payne earned Best Director and Best Screenplay alongside co-writer Jim Taylor. The film also secured acting honors for Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is a strong contender at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. Now in their 20th year, the awards celebrate films made outside the traditional studio system and are held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role in *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also Oscar-nominated. Joshua Marston received Best First Screenplay for the same film.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' of 2004, surpassing stars like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone*'s annual list. He earned $56.5 million (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his *Musicology* tour and album. Madonna secured second place with $54.9 million (£29.5m) from her global *Re-Invention* tour. Simon & Garfunkel ranked 10th, earning $24.9 million (£13.4m) from their comeback tour. "Prince reclaimed the spotlight after a decade away from commercial success," the magazine noted. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5m) in ticket sales, while *Musicology* sold 1.9 million copies.

Walmart fights back against critics as two major U.S. companies launch advertising campaigns to clarify their products and corporate practices. The world's largest retailer placed over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers, aiming to counter criticism regarding its wages, benefits, and promotion policies. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly is preparing a campaign to refute "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart initiated the effort with ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from CEO Lee Scott. He stated it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth," adding, "Many 'urban myths' circulate about Walmart, but facts remain facts.

The Conservatives have unveiled plans for local communities to elect their own police commissioners. Party leader Michael Howard stated this new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities but wouldn’t override chief constables. The Lib Dems warned the proposal could empower extreme groups, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory policing promises. Responding, Jan Berry, chair of the Police Federation of England and Wales, stressed the need to retain operational independence. "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around during elections," she said. Berry also cautioned that the plans risked letting extreme political views dictate on-the-ground operations.

At a glance: The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here’s a breakdown of the proposal: Individuals moving to Britain from outside the EU who intend to stay six months or more—and are from high-TB countries—would require a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. Those from outside the European Union planning to stay a year or longer must undergo a full medical examination, screening for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa rejection, while other conditions would be assessed case by case.

Paris Promise Raises Welsh Hopes. Has there ever been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can Wales' revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions are on the minds of not just Welsh supporters but rugby fans everywhere after a scintillating display. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, called it "one of the great performances of the past 30 years." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, described it as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in." A dejected France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and a Welsh half."

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at number one. Their album follows the single *Black and White Town*, which peaked at number six.  

R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs also have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher.  

Elvis Presley’s re-release, *(Marie’s the Name) His Latest Flame*, enters at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud’s *Wake Me Up*. Akon’s *Locked Up* sits at five, while Kaiser Chiefs’ *Oh My God* lands at six.

Davies favors Gloucester future  
Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he prefers to stay put.  

Davies, a standout in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his value to the Zurich Premiership side and is expected to secure a new deal next season.  

The Celtic Warriors' collapse left Davies sidelined, forcing him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Though he played for the Ospreys at Wales' request, he admitted frustration over his treatment before joining Gloucester.
