Ministers are displeased with plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has admitted. Chancellor Gordon Brown redirected £512m from central to local budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday.  

Raynsford revealed holding "frank discussions" with colleagues over the move but stressed that councils must maintain quality services without steep tax increases. The central funds form part of a £1bn package to help English local authorities limit next year’s council tax rises below 5%—a likely election year.  

Raynsford noted that nearly all central departments have a stake in well-managed local governments.

An Israeli club is turning to Africa, with four African players—including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro—set to feature for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab team to compete in European football, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a key role in their 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. After a short spell with South African club Hellenic, he recently joined the Israeli side. Based near Haifa in Sakhnin, the club won last season's Israeli Cup and is renowned for its strong ethics and commitment to promoting peace and cooperation in Israel.

A new report suggests that reducing drink-drive limits by a third could save more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would prevent 65 deaths annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs voting on the government’s Road Safety Bill, which addresses speeding fines but not drink-drive limits.  

Transport expert Professor Richard Allsop’s study also predicts 230 fewer serious road injuries compared to 2003, saving the UK £119m yearly. A 1998 Department of Transport estimate had projected only 50 lives saved annually with such a change.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single particle in the depletion region, while the array offers a 512×512 μm² detection area. Rather than sensing voltage drop from radiation, the system measures pulse width—the time for voltage to return to baseline—eliminating the need for power-hungry ADCs. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS, consumes 0.535 mW static power at 1.2 V supply. The system is successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would readily accept external control by a central authority is unrealistic. This paper proposes a joint routing and pricing control scheme to incentivize AVs toward centrally optimized routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, while the lower level employs a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model for mixed AV-HV fleets.

Optomechanics and electromechanics now enable macroscopic mechanical oscillators to be prepared in quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond pushing larger objects into the quantum regime, this capability has spurred ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing, communication, and as ultra-precise force sensors surpassing the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to richer quantum states, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early proposals suggested overcoming this limitation through strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, nonclassical states of motion remain elusive.

Online reviews offer valuable product evaluations to guide customer decisions. However, these assessments can be distorted by fake reviews ("spams") from professional spammers, who continually refine deceptive strategies to evade detection. Spamming tactics are difficult to track, as they evolve rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and often remain undiscovered. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize accuracy, which does not fully align with preserving evaluation trustworthiness. To tackle these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete based on practical objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. Nash equilibria in this game yield robust detectors resilient to mixed spamming strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To achieve high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We quantify robustness as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we analyze the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist, even in well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that all local minima exhibit a shared structural form, partially identifying the true component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussians to one true component or fitting one Gaussian to multiple true components, without overlap. Our findings hold when the true components meet a separation condition and remain valid even if the component count is misspecified. For three-component Gaussian mixtures, we derive sharper results based on the separation scaling.

We examine the relationship between two mirror partner constructions for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold arises as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( x_m \) in weighted projective space, defined by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) by a dual group \( g^t \). The second, Batyrev construction, defines the mirror as a hypersurface in a toric variety associated with the reflexive polytope dual to the original orbifold's polytope. We provide a straightforward verification of their equivalence.

In this work, we generalize the study of human gait by building upon existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. Our hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy during locomotion with a nonlinear description of the mass center's libration to reproduce walk-run transition behavior. Experimental results across various speed regimes show that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center is a key metric for quantifying this dynamic. The experimental procedure was conducted in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences department, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems, designed to fully resolve close encounters. The method employs time regularization to preserve symplectic stability while dynamically reducing the step size during planetary encounters. Using a high-order MVS scheme, the integrator maintains large time steps in weakly perturbed regions, such as the solar system. Our algorithm accurately resolves near-collisions (within a fraction of a physical radius) without adjusting the time-step. We validate its long-term performance on six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Compared to hybrid methods like Mercury, our approach delivers superior energy conservation at comparable computational cost.

Entanglement is a fundamental resource in quantum information processing. A common method for detecting entanglement is through entanglement witnesses, where the witness operator yields positive results for all separable states and may be negative for certain entangled states. However, due to the exponential growth of Hilbert-space dimension with system size, constructing efficient entanglement witnesses for general multipartite states remains highly challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and tolerates up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states needs only two local measurements and tolerates up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We introduce a general method to extract multipole moments from arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to horizonless microstate geometries. These can deviate from the axial and equatorial symmetry of Kerr, exhibiting a richer multipolar structure that offers a phenomenological window into fuzzball models. Our numerical analysis suggests their multipole moments typically exceed (in absolute value) those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current quadrupole measurements of black-hole candidates impose only weak constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future LISA observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals will refine these bounds significantly.

Analyzing evolving graphs presents a significant challenge across domains like bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We examine a scenario where edges represent either transient interactions (e.g., messaging) or enduring connections (e.g., friendships). Typically, long-term edges are human-defined, which can be costly and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address this, we introduce a model combining temporal point processes with variational autoencoders, which learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing their interactions. Since temporal attention governs feature propagation between nodes, learning this component from interaction dynamics offers greater adaptability while circumventing the limitations of human-specified edges.

"Thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are observed. The pcw comprises two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models are developed and validated to transduce beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe in a guided mode (gm), both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Designed for near-field atom trapping, this study assesses potential thermal motion effects on optical atomic traps near pcw surfaces. Long-term objectives include establishing strong atom-mediated coupling between individual phonons and single photons in pcw gms, enabling quantum-level optomechanics with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors evaluated at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups in adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. These splittings are motivated by equivariant stable homotopy theory. Since the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, the splittings ensure that certain long exact sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, these splittings yield the regularity of Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The uncertain shape and amplitude of this suppression pose significant challenges for future cosmological weak lensing surveys like *Euclid* or *LSST*. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to create a *Euclid*-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method from Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator for rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling a likelihood inference analysis of a standard ΛCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, like those in child-centered recordings, are among the most challenging audio files to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such diverse conditions would greatly benefit language acquisition studies. Researchers can analyze the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce, aiding early diagnosis and remediation assessment. In this paper, we introduce an open-source neural network designed to classify audio segments into vocalizations by the child wearing the recorder, other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. For this purpose, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages.

Density-based clustering groups data by identifying features of the underlying probability distribution. By referencing the true population structure, the clustering problem can be framed within a standard inferential framework, where the ideal population clustering is defined by the true density function. The nonparametric version, called modal clustering, associates groups with the domains of attraction of density modes. Practically, this requires a nonparametric density estimate, and selecting the right smoothing level—which influences both the density shape and modal structure—is key to determining the final partition. Here, we examine density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic viewpoint.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to interference between Standard Model processes and higher-dimension operators parameterizing new physics effects. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes suppress naïve interference contributions from dimension-six operators, causing leading corrections to the total diboson rate to cancel. Precise measurements of azimuthal decay angles can recover this interference, restoring sensitivity to "non-interfering" operators. We analyze these signatures in detail, demonstrating that uncertainties from higher-dimensional operators are effectively suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable exclusively generated by non-interfering operators. This relegates interfering higher-dimensional operator effects to the same level as statistical uncertainties in the observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a key objective in health and social sciences research. Yet, academic statistics has traditionally viewed causal analyses with skepticism. The emergence of "data science" presents an opportunity to redefine data analysis, seamlessly integrating causal inference. Following prior work, we categorize data science contributions into three tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). Clear classification is essential to outline the data, assumptions, and methods needed for each task. We contend that neglecting the role of domain expertise in data analysis fuels widespread misconceptions about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. Conventionally, these particles ensure extremal black holes are unstable or marginally stable, yet the consequences of violating this condition remain unclear. Here, we demonstrate that in a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. Resolving this tension yields a nonperturbative formulation of the WGC, which simplifies to the standard version at weak coupling. Our argument is broadly applicable, relying neither on supersymmetry nor a specific UV completion, but only on the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems exhibit unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains a key challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases serve as pristine, tunable models to explore the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity has been elusive. Here, we reveal superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by dragging a periodic potential through the system and observing dissipationless flow below a critical velocity \(v_{\rm c}\). We determine \(v_{\rm c}\) across interaction strengths, peaking in the crossover between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This result solidifies ultracold Fermi gases as a versatile platform for probing dimensionality effects in strongly correlated superfluids.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions comprising a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) coupled to an $s$-wave superconductor. The differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit strong dependence on the angle between the junction direction and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We analyze how a chiral chemical potential—the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—affects junction transport. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in both WSM regions. This polarization is opposite in the two regions and highly sensitive to both chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be an effective and precise method for modifying surface electrical conductivity, with applications in diverse fields. Notably, it enables voltage grading across high-voltage insulators, enhancing their operational limits by preventing surface flashover. However, a key concern is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly when the implanted metal is prone to oxidation. This study investigates the durability of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Findings reveal an initial 40% conductivity drop within weeks post-implantation, followed by a gradual decline of approximately 10% over the subsequent year.

We present a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, derived from hidden local symmetry. The associated charge matches the skyrmion charge for smooth configurations. Furthermore, singular configurations can be identified as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under this symmetry. Here, vector mesons act as Chern-Simons fields on the quantum Hall droplet forming the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We argue this current accurately represents the low-energy baryon current. This framework unifies both baryon types, enabling smooth transformations between them. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet arise from a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides a fascinating platform to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, termed anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. By extending the Furusaki-Tsukada formula—originally developed to quantify conventional Josephson tunneling currents—we evaluate transverse current components and show their amplitudes can be widely tuned via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference. As a distinct spectroscopic signature, well-localized subgap bound states emerge near the interface.

Following the suggestion from Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul. 2020) that dipoles are as crucial to decaying two-dimensional turbulence dynamics as individual vortex cores, we find the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed from dipole concatenation. Vortices separate into small, fast-moving cores and larger, slow-moving ones, the latter appearing 'frozen' in a slowly evolving 'crystal.' Their kinematics differ significantly, with only the former being self-similar. The slow component holds most of the flow's kinetic energy, forming dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for its growth are also discussed.

Continuous-time quantum walks are a powerful framework for designing quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of such algorithms is determined by the quantum hitting time—the duration needed for the walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. Here, we present enhanced upper bounds for quantum hitting times applicable to various CTQW-based algorithms. Specifically, we refine the glued-trees problem's hitting time from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$, achieving a polynomial improvement. Additionally, our techniques exponentially enhance the precision dependence in the continuous-time quantum walk algorithm by Chakraborty et al. for finding marked nodes in ergodic, reversible Markov chains.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized as dry or wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, traditionally viewed as the primary sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, arise from multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we emphasize an alternative formation channel: (wet) EMRI formation facilitated by accretion flows around galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). Here, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes on inclined orbits, driving their migration toward the MBH—dramatically enhancing EMRI formation rates in such galaxies.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack information about them—no item interactions, no user profile, and no social connections. Despite this, we expect recommender systems to engage users immediately, encouraging them to stay and become active. This challenge, known as the new user cold-start problem, is critical for a company's growth and sustainability. Existing solutions either demand extra user effort, such as interviews, or rely on side information like demographics, locations, or social ties [10]. However, users may resist interviews, and such data is often unavailable for cold-start scenarios.

Deep learning has overcome numerous challenges beyond heuristic algorithms' reach and has proven effective in wireless communications, despite existing optimal solutions for many radio system tasks. While learning individual receiver components has yielded some improvements, jointly optimizing the entire receiver offers greater potential. However, this often leads to complex nonlinear problems with impractical optimal solutions. To address this, we introduce deeprx, a fully convolutional neural network that processes the entire receiver pipeline—from frequency domain signals to uncoded bits—in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully structuring the network's input with both data and pilot symbols, we enable precise channel estimation.

Mutation-based fuzzing relies on an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. Often, these corpora contain thousands of similar inputs, reducing diversity and potentially wasting fuzzing effort through redundant mutations. To mitigate this, fuzzers employ distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds capable of triggering the same instrumentation coverage as the full corpus. Minimizing both the number and cumulative size of seeds is widely believed to enhance fuzzing efficiency—a claim we systematically investigate. We analyze results from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to assess their effectiveness in discovering real-world software bugs.

This paper examines multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents are grouped based on isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational complexity remain constant regardless of the number of agents. This supervisor maintains its validity under partial observation without requiring recomputation when agents are added or removed. We extend prior results by establishing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. An illustrative example demonstrates the proposed supervisory synthesis approach.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is introduced, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. Leveraging the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix, a Gohberg-Semencul factorization is employed. Notably, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation, particularly with short 1-second time windows in power recordings. For speech recordings, it achieves high accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency.

The **direpack** package introduces a collection of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques to Python as a unified, cohesive toolkit. It categorizes these methods into three groups: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, it offers regularized regression estimators derived from these reduced spaces, spanning from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, **direpack** seamlessly integrates estimators into statistical or machine learning pipelines within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission is widely used for high-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence saturation effect in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing emission nonlinearity and altering the image's spatial frequency distribution. A differential excitation protocol was employed to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, this method holds promise for enhancing spatial resolution in sensing and biological labeling using solid-state defects.

When random effects correlate with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights (constructed as inverses of unit inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fails to yield asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased inference for hyperparameters. Our method is contrasted with frequentist approaches relying on numerical integration, showing that only the Bayesian framework achieves both design-unbiased estimation and consistency with the population-generating distribution. Simulations and a real-world business survey application demonstrate our approach’s versatility across models and sampling designs. This work culminates recent efforts integrating traditional survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging two historically distinct sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene—exhibit more intricate atomic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, strong nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic responses, and superconductivity. Additionally, low symmetry enables unique electronic topological traits, nonlinear elastic behaviors, and structural phase transitions. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic showcases cutting-edge experimental and theoretical research on these materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was observed that in a mesogenic polymer—unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens—the relaxation of electric birefringence above the nematic-isotropic transition temperature can be described by multiple exponential processes, with two playing a dominant role. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further revealed two orientational relaxation mechanisms: one arising from rotation of the side mesogenic groups and the other linked to main chain segment motion.

Deep hashing methods demonstrate strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency for large-scale image retrieval. A key focus in these methods is optimizing discrete hash bits. Typically, an activation function like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$ is used, alongside quantization loss minimization, to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can trap hash bits in incorrect saturated regions of the activation functions, preventing recovery. We term this issue the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Moreover, existing quantization loss exacerbates dbp. To address this, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We examine scenarios where the triplet is either stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by LHC disappearing-track searches and direct detection experiments, while the decaying triplet faces limits from multilepton collider searches. Our analysis shows that a two-step electroweak phase transition with a stable triplet (having a negative quadratic term) is excluded by direct detection. Additionally, an unstable triplet with a mass below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is ruled out at $95\%$ confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings around Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). The conventional scenario assumes an initially circular, narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity is raised to \(e_f\) via secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after gas disc dispersal, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight modification allows for narrower belts if planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly due to earlier planetary perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity could stem from disc instabilities, independent of planets.

An electron is typically thought to possess only one form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model effectively describes interacting electrons at low energies, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We detect two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with three additional 1D "replica" modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is tuned by adjusting 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The Milky Way's assembly history is being revealed through data from the $Gaia$ mission. The galaxy's globular cluster system likely followed an equally complex formation path. $aims$. To constrain this path, we examine the connection between globular clusters and the Milky Way's known merger events. $methods$. We combine $Gaia$'s kinematic data for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, corrected for systematic errors. By analyzing their dynamical properties, especially in integrals of motion space, we identify clusters with shared origins. $results$. Approximately 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package implementing state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the TWO-NN, Gride, and Hidalgo models. To ensure accessibility, *intrinsic* provides high-level, intuitive functions built upon efficient low-level routines. The package features models divided into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category comprises TWO-NN and Gride, with functions supporting both frequentist and Bayesian inference. The second category includes Hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, we propose and model two physical RC systems: one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), designed for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations reveal that an RC system employing a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Furthermore, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as demonstrated in second-order nonlinear dynamic and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are vital for online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper reveals an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items reporting a signal, the greater their collective share of traffic. This "few-get-richer" effect arises when items fall into limited distinct categories (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news) and are ranked by popularity. We analytically show this effect occurs when users click top-ranked items and exhibit diverse preferences across categories. Through simulations, we examine how the effect’s intensity varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We further validate our predictions via an online experiment with human participants. These findings offer critical insights into misinformation dissemination.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across platforms. However, most pruning techniques compromise between accuracy and regularity, often degrading inference performance and limiting on-device speed. To address this, we introduce pattern-based sparsity—a novel dimension combining pattern and connectivity sparsity—delivering both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. Our meticulously designed patterns enable unprecedented accuracy improvements and enhanced feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our framework integrates pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training seamlessly. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, ensuring efficient DNN execution on mobile devices.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from the treated group risks bias from historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall controls may reduce bias. We examine this phenomenon through simulations. Specifically, we analyze the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach, leveraging the rise in MRM after the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For this analysis, we developed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval encompassing substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When building models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This evaluation can be performed using visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve: (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study from the model, (2) computing key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data, particularly when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated post-event.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We demonstrate how protocols combining repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses can: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence, aligning with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predict the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally reconstruct environmental noise spectral density by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for quantum-sensor design. These advancements will improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technology.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it would be mortifying. No, you aren’t being stalked by a monster; you’re speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. When you’re dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. Yet at some point, we’ve all had to address a crowd, so you must learn to overcome it. First, understand what stage fright is. Humans, as social creatures, are wired to care about reputation. Public speaking threatens that. Before a speech, you panic: *What if they think I’m terrible?*

I can't think of anyone with just one interest in life, content to do only that forever. [The way we work], around 15% of American workers lack traditional full-time jobs—they're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term 'side hustle' aligns with this ethos, as people combine multiple roles to earn a living. The phrase 'side hustle' originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, 'hustle' referred to scams, but by the 1950s, 'side hustle' also described legitimate work. Unlike a second job driven by necessity, a side hustle offers flexibility.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is crafted from thousands of steel parts, the other woven from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes itself on the environment, the other emerges from it. One is designed for nature, the other by her. Michelangelo believed raw marble held a figure yearning to break free. His chisel was his sole tool. Yet life isn’t carved—it grows. Within our cells, the smallest units of life, lies all the information needed for function and replication. Tools shape outcomes. Since the Industrial Revolution, design has been governed by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people say if you get nervous onstage, picture the audience naked? It’s supposed to help, but imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels strange and outdated. We’re working hard to move past that, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. I realized what would really help is if I could look at you as much as you look at me—just to balance things out. So if I had way more eyeballs, we’d all be comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This brilliant critique of multitasking is often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus—though, as with many quotes, he likely never said it. But my real question is: Is it true? Certainly, it applies to emailing at dinner, texting while driving, or live-tweeting a TED Talk. Yet I’d argue that for certain important tasks, doing two—or even three or four—things at once is exactly the goal. Take Albert Einstein: in 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to be better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania—home of Bethlehem Steel—my father, an engineer, taught me how things worked. We built projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here’s the go-kart we made—that’s me behind the wheel with my sister and best friend. One day when I was around 10, he came home and announced at dinner that our next project would be... a robot. A robot.

Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is caught. But the who and why matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my meals, how I affect them, and how they affect me. I want to understand why they fish and how they depend on the water’s bounty for their livelihood. Grasping this shifts our view of seafood from a commodity to a chance to heal our ecosystem. It lets us appreciate the seafood we’re lucky to enjoy. So what do we call this? Restorative seafood. While sustainability is about enduring, restoration is about replenishing and progressing.

The starving orphan begging for a second helping of gruel. The spinster fading away in her tattered wedding gown. The miser, hardened by greed, haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. Over a century after his death, these remain iconic figures from Charles Dickens’s work. His writing is so distinctive that it inspired its own adjective. But what makes Dickens’s prose truly remarkable? His fiction thrives on suspense, crafted through atmospheric settings, unexpected twists, and lingering mysteries. These elements captivated his audience, leaving them eager for more. Originally, his tales were serialized—released in affordable literary journals chapter by chapter—before being compiled into books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision—these are the traits shared by the greatest achievers. These are the fearless souls for whom failure is never an option. What seems like an insurmountable challenge to us is merely the stage our next speaker was destined to conquer. So let’s dive into the inspiring story of Bhakti Sharma, a trailblazer in long-distance swimming. (Applause)  

Bhakti Sharma: Picture this—a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan. A two-and-a-half-year-old clings to her mother on a moped, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, that child finds herself fully submerged in water.

I'm going to discuss a groundbreaking technology we're developing at Oxford, which we believe will revolutionize how computer games and Hollywood movies are made. This innovation involves simulating humans—complete with a virtual body and nervous system to control it. Before diving deeper, let's briefly examine current human characters in games. Here's a clip from *Grand Theft Auto 3*, which we glimpsed yesterday. As you can see, it's an exceptional game and one of the most successful ever created.

Like many people worldwide, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France. We watched incredible athletes score amazing goals in clean, engaging matches, while off the field, these women advocated for equal pay—or any pay at all in some countries. Our mild obsession led us to watch the games live, and we chose a Spanish-speaking network in the U.S. as our go-to. A few games in, a friend turned to me and asked, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is ads for makeup, cleaning products, and diets?

Let me tell you about the future of money. It begins with a story of the Yap, a culture in Micronesia during the early 1900s. Their form of currency was fascinating—they used massive limestone discs called Rai stones. Unlike modern coins, the Yap didn’t physically exchange these stones due to their enormous size; some weighed up to four tons and spanned 12 feet. Instead, they simply recorded ownership. There’s even a tale of sailors transporting one across the ocean when disaster struck, and the stone sank.

You’ve been accused of a crime you didn’t commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession—or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to supernatural paranoia, misguided religious fervor—and a justice system that prized repentance over truth. Salem was founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants. Life there was strict and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were common.

Currently, hundreds of thousands of people await life-saving transplants for organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers. Sadly, donor organs fall far short of meeting this demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could produce new, customized organs? This is the vision behind bioprinting, an emerging field in regenerative medicine. While complex organs remain beyond our reach, simpler tissues—such as blood vessels and nutrient-exchange tubes—are already achievable. Bioprinting is akin to 3D printing, building three-dimensional structures layer by layer, but with biological materials.

Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll discuss a phenomenon that is actively transforming our world: people power. I'll begin with an anecdote—or for Monty Python fans, a sketch-like scenario. Imagine it's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet: peer into a crystal ball to see an accurate future, but you must share it with the world. Curiosity wins—you accept. One hour later, you're on a national TV show, recounting what you saw.

We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23 years old, is at the peak of his career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small group of critics accuse him of stealing others' work.  

Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *Black Album* to create *The Grey Album*. It quickly becomes an online sensation. The Beatles' label responds with cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Today, *The Grey Album* stands as a groundbreaking remix.

Well, that’s a rather obvious observation. I began with that statement nearly 12 years ago, focusing on developing countries, but you’re here from every corner of the world. Picture a map of your country, and you’ll realize that for every nation, you could mark areas where good teachers refuse to work. Worse, these are often the very places where trouble arises. It’s an ironic dilemma—good teachers avoid the regions that need them most. In 1999, I launched an experiment in New Delhi to tackle this issue—a simple yet bold initiative.

Currently, most refugees reside in urban areas rather than camps, representing over 60% of refugees worldwide. Given this reality, a paradigm shift is urgently needed. Instead of investing in barriers, funds should support programs empowering refugees to become self-reliant. (Applause) Though we often leave behind possessions, we retain our skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity, refugees can thrive and contribute meaningfully to their host communities. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth of twelve children.

"I have two questions for you. First: whose shoulders do you stand on? Second: what do you stand for? I always start my poetry workshops with these because poetry can sometimes feel like a dead art form for old white men who seem born to be ancient—like Benjamin Button. I ask my students these questions, then share my own answers in three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These words are my mantra before every poetry performance—I was even reciting them earlier, making faces in the corner.

(Breathes in) (Breathes out) So, I didn’t always make my living from music. For nearly five years after graduating from a respected liberal arts university, this was my day job. (Laughter) I worked as a self-employed living statue called the Eight-Foot Bride, and I love telling people about it because everyone wonders, 'Who are these performers in real life?' (Laughter) Hello. One day, I painted myself white, stood on a box, placed a hat or can at my feet, and whenever someone dropped in money, I gave them a flower—along with intense eye contact. If they refused the flower, I’d add a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, humanity's first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, barely two feet wide, ignited an eighteen-year space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R., reshaping history. However, Sputnik wasn’t the first human-made object in space. That distinction belongs to Germany’s V-2 rocket, deployed in WWII’s final years for missile strikes against Allied cities. Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—is burdened by centuries of stigma, reduced to a topic many still whisper about. But why? From my experience and that of countless women, I can say it’s exhausting. Exhausting to furtively pull out a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, tuck it into your pocket mid-class, and rush discreetly to the washroom. Exhausting to sit through lessons or meetings, pretending everything’s fine while enduring agonizing cramps.

Globally among the most threatened ecosystems, wetlands perform vital functions: purifying air and water, storing greenhouse gases, and supporting immense biodiversity. These fragile landscapes are absolutely crucial to our planet's health.

In 1903, the U.S. president embarked on a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. Theodore Roosevelt slept among towering sequoias, weathered a snowstorm, and shared campfire conversations with his host, conservationist John Muir. Though Roosevelt adored the outdoors, Muir’s invitation had a greater purpose: Yosemite was under threat. Despite gaining protected status in 1864, the valley faced overdevelopment by 1903. It stood at the center of a long-standing effort to preserve land for both conservation and public enjoyment—goals far harder to achieve than to declare. The conflict over Yosemite traces back to the 1849 Gold Rush, when miners flooded the Sierra Nevada foothills in search of gold.

Imagine if you could connect your mind to a machine offering lifelong, unparalleled pleasure. If given the choice, would you embrace such an existence? It challenges us to envision a world where scientists have created a device capable of simulating reality—delivering only pleasure and no pain. The catch? You must abandon reality permanently, though the difference would be imperceptible. Your simulated experiences would feel entirely real, replacing life’s natural highs and lows with ceaseless euphoria. Sounds perfect, doesn’t it?

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon is part of a natural cycle, present in all living things: in soil, oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants absorb it again. Over millions of years, some carbon from ancient trees and marine life forms rocks or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, release carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release this ancient carbon. Today, humans emit about 60 times more carbon annually than all the world’s volcanoes combined.

Even nature's most repulsive creatures hold vital secrets, but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches? Yet a key distinction between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex, unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing rough terrain. Equipped with jet packs or subjected to disturbances like earthquakes, their finely tuned legs enable self-stabilization without cognitive input. They navigate complex landscapes like grass effortlessly, maintaining stability. We observed a novel behavior: their body shape allows them to automatically roll sideways to maneuver through artificial grass patches. Robust systems can execute multiple functions with a single structure—revealing yet another remarkable adaptation.
